 Jimmy McCarron is intimately acquainted with fear. Not that he feels it, but he spends most of his life causing it. He knows that he's the kind of man that people are afraid of. Or if they're not, and they give him a reason -- which admittedly, he doesn't need much -- they learn to be afraid of him. It's in the way he carries himself, the innate self-confidence that says he knows exactly what he's capable of and trusts himself in such a way that nothing will rattle his iron nerves. In his eyes, their intense blue, that always say there's more ticking in his head than what he shows. Man or monster, nobody knows, but there's always a higher level in his thoughts. Not that he's not also, at five foot ten with his precise manner of speech and his no-bullshit attitude, capable of roughing somebody up or forcing the point. Everything about Jimmy McCarron screams that he was built to be a war machine and he knows what he is. He embraces the antagonism. He takes no egotistical pleasure in making people afraid of him, but to him, it's no matter. It's just part of what he does. What he does, after all, is all that he is. One day with people afraid of what he's capable of...is just another ordinary day. Muse: Detective Jimmy McCarron Fandom: L.A. Dragnet Word Count: 256

South. Some people say I'm from the South. But it's a stretch. I was born in Savannah, Georgia. But I was raised in the Bronx, and I live in Los Angeles, so it's not like I have any particular Southern heritage. I don't even have an accent. My partner says I have a faint New York accent, but half of what he says is bullshit. I work in Southern California. LAPD Robbery Homicide Division day shift. The supervisor is Captain Ruth Hagermann. My partner is Ryan Sheridan, one of the two supervising sergeants, and he's a stand-up guy, even if he hasn't gotten over the shock of having stripes on his dress uniform yet. I just wish he would shut up about his wife and his desire for kids. Some of us don't live in a domestic fantasy. But that's Los Angeles. Nobody is happy with what they have. Everybody wants to be someone else. It's all about who has it and who wants it, and what they're willing to do to get it. And if that involves committing a crime, then I have full license to show up at your door and kick your ass for it. ... This was a complete waste of my time. What is something that has happened to you that has helped shape the person you are today? Frank Smith got a girlfriend. I'm sure he's had one before; it's not as if I keep track of his social life. He's not a homicidal maniac, and he's got that annoying retriever look on his face, I'm sure someone found him attractive at some point. But four years ago there was a federal agent who got involved in one of our cases and he was smitten. He volunteered to do her protective detail when somebody tried to kill her, and mooned after her the whole time after until she finally agreed to go on a date with him. None of this had shit to do with me. But this girl kept showing up, from that first case to the SWAT standoff that came after. She was in my space and as a result, in my life. He was falling all over her, and she wasn't noticing. And I didn't notice her until we ran into each other in the parking lot. We started talking. Frank flipped, of course, telling her I wasn't worth her time. She didn't listen to him. I liked that about her. Besides, what did it matter, he got the girl anyway. He was happy. She needed some help, from somebody who wouldn't be afraid of unpredictable situations. After I'd saved her in that SWAT standoff, she thought I had what it took to do the job. I liked the challenge. Jimmy McCarron trusts her enough to not grab her by the wrist and tell her she's being stupid, or to throw her boyfriend up against a wall and commit a dissection of his soul. Because really, every time he looks at Brittany since they got off that Concorde at LAX, the prevailing thought in his head has been What the fuck is going on with you? His philosophy is that it's her life, and he will not stop her from doing whatever she wants to do. However, that philosophy never implied or required understanding whatever it is she wants to do. Usually he's good at following her logic; they're both smart people with solid common sense. Annoyance at himself for not getting it; confusion because this is so far out of line for her he can't even see where she's standing anymore. What is your most treasured possession and why? He doesn't even have it anymore, and it didn't mean a thing to him, really, until he let it go. That stupid platitude about not knowing what you've got until it's gone comes into his mind, but that's not it at all. The Saint Christopher medallion was sitting in a drawer somewhere, probably had been there for a while, since whenever he had lost his faith, if he'd ever really had any faith. He had come across it and sat there looking at it, and somehow he knew she would get good use out of it. Not that she was religious, either, but for other reasons. Christopher was the patron saint of holy death, for one, and she was convinced she was on her way to a noble demise. He was also no longer a saint, just human, and she was the best example of what humanity could be and how it could be constructive without being naive or otherwise falsified. That, and as long as she had it, part of him was with her and vice versa, in some weird way. He wasn't normally one for stupid emotional gestures like that, but with her he wanted her to know he would always be standing in the shadows waiting for her to find him a next challenge, next crucible. He loved those battles, and she provided them. She kept him alive. Life turned to love, but love had been buried now, turned to an alliance that was unlike any other. She's gone now, having left to be with somebody he doesn't really know, leaving him and her now ex-husband to fight on without her. It bothers him for the unknown. He's gone back to his normalcy as a homicide detective and nothing more, but he knows you don't ever go back after being the shadow to a counterterrorism agent with a personal destiny to save the world or die trying. He knows she's got him and he's got her and that's the way life is now. And he knows that before and after she put that gun to her chin, she's had that medallion around her neck. Christopher will deliver her to a holy death, but as long as she's alive, he'll be with her. That fight they've got to finish is more important than anything else before or after.

Jimmy McCarron leaned back in his chair, staring off into space. T.J. McCabe walked through the room and glanced at him, not having to ask why McCarron was in a bizarre state of mind. Days earlier, T.J. - sober, straightened out, and now a successful SWAT cop studying for his sergeant's exam thanks to one move pulled by an absentee CTU agent - had decided to go visit his estranged brother Miles in Boston. To T.J. it was the last fence he needed to mend. 

He'd been surprised when McCarron had insisted on coming with, but then the surprise had faded and that was why he'd agreed to let his best friend come along. Jimmy partly wanted to make sure T.J. was okay, but months later he didn't have to nursemaid him anymore. No, Boston wasn't too far from Princeton, New Jersey, where Brittany now made her home. He was going to call her. He wanted to see her. To make sure this insane risk of hers had all worked out.

McCarron had settled into the role of playmaker that she'd turned over to him, and things were going decently, but the traffic was nowhere near what it had been when she had made the connections. They'd lost Tom Quinn, for one, and for two they just didn't connect so much without her there. He spent most of his time devoted back to his work as a homicide detective...but he missed the flashes of difference. Faith was in Boston, or so he heard. He wanted to see her, too. Imagined he'd have to tell her everything about the London trip, Brittany's new boyfriend, her sudden departure...didn't know what she'd say.

He sighed and picked up the phone, dialing the cell phone number she'd given him and wondering if it was still the same. Very little else was in his life anymore. Only now did he realize he cared about that.

What is so important to you that without it, life is not worth living? Why? It's been two days since they beat the odds and won the battle they weren't supposed to win, but two days later, Jimmy McCarron sits in the LAPD Robbery Homicide Squadroom at his desk and he is as concerned for the woman he loves as he was when they were out in the field and she had a gun to her head. Maybe even more so, because he knew what she'd do with the gun. He doesn't know what she'll do now. He considers the evidence, like he always does, pretending it's not personal, though it obviously is. He knows her husband - her soulmate, the man she has pinned her identity to, his recent friend and confidante in the face of everything that had once been between them - didn't get on that plane coming home. He knows she locked herself in the back of the plane and wasn't heard from again until it landed. She hasn't said what happened there, but he didn't go back after her. Some might call it callous; he calls it letting her deal. He knows that she knows he is always behind her. It never has to be said or even shown; it just is what it is. They're different. Still it concerns him. He knows how losing Michael crippled her once and how she swore - they both swore - it wouldn't happen again. He remembers wanting to kill the man for walking back into her life and turning it upside down again when he should have gotten it right the first time. He understands now the past there, but that doesn't make him accepting of it. This is too fragile a situation, this is too wrong a time for him to leave her like this. If McCarron had known what he was planning, he would have stopped it cold. But he didn't, and now Michael is gone and it could all go to hell. McCarron doesn't plan to simply lie in wait. He's colluding with Frank Smith now, his old enemy, her old lover. It's his best move. He asked Frank to go over to CTU and see what the situation was. If he himself had gone, she would know why he had come. With Frank, it's just a friendly visit. Frank came back and reported that everything seemed to be okay, if she was a little busy. That's encouraging, but Jimmy McCarron is a born skeptic. She's too important to him for her to lose herself and for him to lose her. Like it or not, without her around, his world would be a shadow of itself and he realizes that now, with only a trace of the bitterness that once accompanied the thought. He still loves her. He has never stopped loving her. All he did was put it aside because that's what's best for them. With Michael gone, he knows the opening is there, but he won't take it. He won't make a move as a temporary solution, won't let himself be used, won't use her like that. If he is ever to love her, it will be a lifelong thing. Not like this. But the feelings haven't died. They're just now used for other purposes. Right now, all he's concerned with is her and nothing else. He does his job, he lives his life, but she is always on his mind. Namely, what will happen to her if Michael Colefield fails her for the third time. The old familiar urge to kill is in his veins again -- surging, crackling, sparking, burning. And the man he once was is back with a vengeance.

Outside Thames House, London MI5 Central HQ 5:45 A.M. local time Sitting in the back of the rental car, Tom Quinn folds his hands in his lap and watches Brittany Colefield and Dana Scully advance on the doorstep of Thames House. He almost wants to smile, knowing MI5 and MI6 will be thrown when the young woman they had hoped never to see again shows up on their doorstep wanting to bring the albatross of his existence or lack thereof back to center stage. There are only a few ways it can go from here. She'll either make her point and he'll be making that walk himself in just a few minutes, or it will all go to hell and he'll be heading back for the safe harbor of the United States. Tom doesn't know which way it will go. He knows full well this game can end with his life being spent in prison or a bullet in the back of his head. In fact, when the phone call came, he assumed that to be the ending. He has done that each of the times she's called him asking for his help; he has to, because those are the stakes. He knows he's very lucky that each of the times he has violated his compact - the industrial action case, Nina Myers' return, the Code Five confrontation - he's managed to escape retribution. He doesn't kid himself that his luck will last forever. He also knows Brittany never calls on him unless she has no other choice. She is still guilty for consigning him to what seems, at times, a fate worse than death. They have stripped him of his country, his identity, his freedom and his belief, but deep down inside, Tom Quinn is still one of the best spies the world has ever seen. Given all that Brittany has done for him - and he still remembers the shouting matches behind closed doors with lawyers, the way she sat emotionlessly at the defendant's table with him, refusing to cut him loose when she could have quit and saved herself - he sees no better use of his talents than saving her life. He understands perfectly why she has asked this time, and he knows that even if his luck runs out today, their relationship sealed his choice from the moment she called. "You don't plan on listening to her, do you?" he asks Jimmy McCarron, the detective sitting in the front seat, the first indication that he'd heard any of the conversation that had just happened. Briefly, Tom wonders if Michael knows his wife is in love with another man, but he knows Michael Colefield isn't stupid. Their short time as allies taught him that. He knows that McCarron, like Michael, is in this for love. Such a noble end. McCarron shifts in his seat, glancing back over his shoulder at Tom. His eyes are hard, intensely burning, firmly set on what's ahead of him. "I don't know. It'll depend on the situation. If I think I can save her, I won't leave her." He pauses, taking in the spy he's worked with before but doesn't seem to know. "If it was you, what would you do?" "I'd listen to her." Tom sighed. "Knowing what I know about Harry, as soon as my name gets dropped, they'll be searching the country for me. She's collateral damage. I'd rather protect some of my agents and leave the rest to fight on than get us all strung up before the real target can even get pinned down." He paused. "The problem is there's too many ways it can go. It can go well, and we walk out of here together and get Lindsay. It can go badly, and you and I end up back in the States while the rest of the team goes to ground and tries to deal with both her and him. Or it can go exceptionally badly and the whole thing can be fucked. There's no way to tell, because we don't know what anyone will do." "That thought had occurred to me," McCarron agreed, eyes constantly on the move in case of a threat. "There are too many options. Too many things out of our control." He bristled, and Tom could see it. This was personal for him, as if the kiss hadn't been a blatant sign of that. "We don't have the luxury of control," Tom informed him. "We're fighting two fronts here. Five can come after me and her or the whole team, depending on how vengeful they feel like being. Lindsay can come after her or all of us. And if it really goes to hell and she gets strung up," he hesitated, "what's to say Lindsay won't find out?" McCarron finished a thought: "And launch a full scale attack on MI5 to get her out." "Control is a myth," Tom repeated in the resulting silence.

Have you ever regretted a wish you made? Write a drabble on the word 'beautiful.' Thames House looms large in the distance: landmark to one friend's betrayal by his own country, location to another's attempted martyrdom. The three of them sit in the car together, staring at it. Dana Scully has already gone on ahead, perhaps sensing that they need a minute. Tom Quinn is laying low in the back seat, and McCarron, with hands firmly on the wheel, notes that the man has gotten too damn good at pretending he doesn't exist. It's almost as if only he and Brittany are there. The thought happens in his brain: Maybe that's the way they were setting it up to be. The way it was pretty much supposed to be in the end. His blue eyes slide from the building in front of them to her, sitting in the passenger seat. She breathes in and out steadily, like a metronome. He surveys her, the perfect soldier. The suit that hides a SigArm P226, an Ehrlich 400, and a HALO Microtech knife, all of which she'll be asked to surrender. CTU badge folder in her right jacket pocket, he knows from memory. Wedding ring on her left ring finger. His Saint Christopher medallion still around his neck. May the patron saint of holy death deliver her to one, if that's what it's going to come to. Twenty years old with twenty-eight, twenty-nine-year-old eyes and beauty in her resolve. "Jimmy," she says. "I want to make sure we're clear on this. You take Tom and get the hell out of here. Don't come back for me. No matter what happens. That's an order. I go down, I go down. Don't come back for me. Please." He thinks of his conversation with Scully - the first time he'd told anyone outside of her and Michael that he loved her. Thinks of how he'd break that promise to her in a heartbeat. Yet he knows why she asked him to make it. "I don't answer to you," he says, just to be itinerant. "But I'll do what you need me to do." She's silent for a moment, perhaps put off by his level tone, the war-ready set of his shoulders. Jimmy McCarron is a lifetime soldier and she knows that. Her attraction to him, and his to her, is based on that darkness that they share. She could no sooner sway him than she could imagine life without him. "You've known it was going to come down to this all along, didn't you?" she says, looking at him levelly. "Not this specifically, but ... You suspected this ending." "Yeah, I have. Why do you think I kept warning you..." He stops himself, realizing tenseness isn't what she needs right now. "What have I always said? It's your life, your fight. Go do what you have to do and don't apologize." They look at each other for a long moment, somewhere in the space of which her hand finds his shoulder and his fingers end up in her hair. He remembers then, as he does often, wishing that she'd break her engagement to be with him. He regrets that now, knowing how happy Michael has made her. They might not have that shared future that was the difference between himself and Colefield, not if she dies today, but he still knows she's best with the man that isn't him. Now he doesn't see it as winning and losing. They're all in this together. Her lips find his and they share one last lingering, passionate, bittersweet kiss. "I love you, Jimmy," she tells him as she opens the door, her hand in his own. "I love you, too," he replies, not looking away, looking right at her, memorizing her. She holds his hand for as long as she can, then she shuts the door and walks away. After Scully. Headlong into that wall this time. Possibly the last time. If this is the ending, he says, watching the woman he loves until she disappears and beginning the countdown in the back of his mind, I have no regrets.

What does the word 'love' mean to you? At this precise moment, as the Air Force jet screams into the air from LAX, love to Jimmy McCarron means being willing to step in front of the bullet that will likely be aimed at Tom Quinn when he returns to England and die for him. If he survives that, love means shoving Brittany Colefield out of the way of whatever Jacob Lindsay aims at her and being willing to die for her, which he knows in his gut he's been capable of for some time now. It's simply what this conflict demands. Love is the word he never said until recently, and thinking on what happened, almost wishes he never said, but doesn't because he never says something he doesn't mean and owns his mistakes. It's what he has with the woman sitting in front of him. It's being willing to kill for her and die for her. It's secrets that he's told and secrets he has kept. It's the desire to possess her and the honest fascination he has when she is unleashed. It's reading her mind, knowing the look in her eyes, feeling her under his skin. But love is letting the woman he loves love the man she has always loved. And never letting that change his love for her or what he is willing to do because of it.

Describe what your "happily ever after" would be like. Reading the prompt, McCarron gives one of his trademark cynical chuckles. "Brittany and Michael must be having a field day with this one," he says to himself, knowing that his close friends' belief in such things is the foundation of their lives and of their success. Sure, it might have been challenged, chipped and jaded over time, but it still exists. It has to, or why the hell would they ever put themselves through this? Even he himself wouldn't turn down the idea of world peace, although he lives on conflict and knows a world without conflict will never exist. After all, he's packing his bags to catch a midnight flight to London for the second huge operation in two years. He shakes his head and spins out of the chair, making the walk from the living room to the bedroom to think on his answer. The suitcase is still sitting on the end of the bed - he's waiting for T.J. to bring the rest of everything by. McCarron's job on this mission is two-fold: not just standard muscle, but he's body man for Tom Quinn, a man who's committing suicide just by showing up in his former country. Detective Jimmy McCarron sat on the table in the bar, holding his pool cue in one hand. Anyone looking at him would have figured him for being out of the game: sleeves rolled up, collar undone, his tie at some odd angle. Yet if you looked in his eyes, their astute and intense gaze fixated on the man straddling the chair in front of him, you would know that he was still thinking like the soldier he was. "She does what she will," he finally said after a long moment.

Michael Colefield nodded, resting his chin on his forearms. Up until recently these two never would have been caught dead together. Now they were friends and allies whose love of the same woman was an alliance, not a division. That was why he had come to McCarron before he'd gone to anyone else. Only McCarron was in his position. "I know," he said, remembering that they had argued over this back when they had been enemies. "And I'll support her to the end of the line, you know that."

"But you think she's making a mistake," McCarron finished the rest of the sentence for him.

Michael hesitated, then sighed. "I don't know, mate. Weiss has been after her constantly to stay, I think she's about ready to clock him. "Almost?"

"He was still wrong," was the explanation. "Anyway, I don't think T.J. knows how to talk to himself right now, let alone her. He could try, but I think it'd just be awkward and potentially hazardous for the both of them. No."

Michael swallowed. "What's your gut instinct telling you about this, McCarron?"

"That I want her to be happy and if she's honestly convinced her happiness is elsewhere, then she needs to go. But that we never expected her to stay. You and I both know this isn't what she is. She was going to leave or she was going to die. We were all prepared for it. I talked to Tom Quinn the other day, he said he hadn't expected her to hang in there this long." He sighed. "But that I can't be her. I'm passable, but I'm not her. I don't know how she deals with people. I had one meeting where I couldn't get a straight answer and it drove me nuts. I don't have the touch she does. So if she goes, I'll be ready, and I can lead on a battlefield, but I can't play peacemaker. That's her alone." He looked straight at Michael when he said, "And I don't want to lose her."

"I don't want to lose her either," Michael agreed. "Although it's been said to me that now might be a good time for us to start a family."

"You guys want kids?"

"Yeah, we do."

McCarron chuckled. "Something else I never could've given her."

"I don't think it will happen, not for a while, anyway. So she doesn't have a gun in her hands. I still do." Michael took a long drink from his beer bottle and glanced away for a long moment. "Would you talk to her?" he said. "Tell her what you feel. She listens to you."

"And she doesn't listen to you?"

"I'm not going to tell her how I feel. I'm supposed to support her unconditionally. So do you, but she listens to you anyway." Michael shrugged. "It's my only thought here. She has to go back in a day or two, and I'm going with her."

McCarron nodded. "I'll give it my best shot. I'll come back with you, take her out for a while, if you didn't have plans."

"I haven't had time to make plans, I'm too busy worrying about all this shit." Michael shook his head. "I've got Mark trying to be her in CTU, you trying to cover for her outside of it, that Burroughs guy coming back in, and rumor is Nick Bryant is pissed about Jack hiring a civilian and is just waiting to come down and raise hell. Then I go home and wonder if any of this is right anymore."

Jimmy McCarron cracked a small smile. "Sounds like par for the course in this world."

Michael chuckled apathetically. "Yeah, I guess it is."

Not that she was wrong, but that taking charge is what I'm here for.

The only problem I have is the voice in my head that misses her and won't die quietly. That, I know I can't do anything about.

Do you believe in the possibility of a true friendship between a man and a woman? McCarron holds the book in his hands. Resurrection Men by Ian Rankin. A good three to four inches thick, it's supposed to be one hell of a novel. Brittany came by the apartment earlier and gave it to him for Christmas. He hadn't expected her to get him anything (although in retrospect he should've figured it out, as generous as she is), practically having forgotten the holiday was coming. It would be another year spent by himself while his brother continued to pretend he didn't exist and vice versa. Why should he care? "I just wanted to bring your Christmas present by. You know, 'cause I didn't see you at the party..." she said by way of explanation. He nodded. "Yeah, not particularly where I wanted to be," he replied, referring to the LAPD Christmas party that he didn't doubt Ryan and Jenna Sheridan, not to mention Brittany and Frank Smith, had all been at a few days earlier. "No offense, but it's not me." "Yeah, I, um ... I didn't really expect to see you there," she admitted in a tone that said she'd been hoping regardless that he'd be found that evening. "Anyway. I didn't want to forget you, before I go. You've been as important to me as anyone this year, Jimmy." "Thank you," he tells her simply. "I'm glad that I could be there for you. We accomplished a lot." "We did, didn't we?" she says, and now she can smile about it, recognize it. There isn't any more skepticism or panic or fear, just a respect for what they've done. He's helped to give her that. She pauses, "I guess we have," she says. "So: thank you for that." She hands him the package. "I should get going," she says, leaning up to kiss him on the cheek. "CTU's having our party tomorrow night. If you change your mind, we'll all be there." "I'll think about it," he says, probably lying. "Take care of yourself," he adds for no real reason at all. "You deserve it." "So do you," she replies, then smiles one last time, turns and is gone. He leans back into the couch, flips the front cover open and reads what she wrote there for the fourth time. A short litany of reasons for which she is grateful to have known him, talking about courage, dedication, endurance. He has no doubt that those qualities exist in her and that without him she would've found them anyway. But still, what she says means something to him, because she means something to him. He still remembers the voices of her better angels and future boyfriend telling her he was nothing but trouble and her never listening. Years later, with this peace they've finally earned, her refusal to let him go seems to mean more than it did in the past. She wanted him to have the hope, the future. It's not hers, it's theirs. That's what she's written here. That he's as entitled to that as she is and that she'd fight to ensure that he had it, never mind that he lives for its antithesis. His well-being is important to her. She treats him better than his own family does. Maybe that's what finally does it. He smiles slightly to himself, sets the book on the coffee table. After a moment, he grabs his jacket off the couch and finds the keys to the Alero, drives the half hour crosstown to CTU Los Angeles. As she said, everyone is there, this party in full motion. McCarron slips in unnoticed, hangs near her old desk, watching her talk with Lex Richards, Santa hat on her head and odd smile on her face. She's happy. She's content. And so, it seems, is he. After a few moments she feels him watching her, gets rid of the hat and makes her way to see him. The relief on her face can't be hidden. She's surprised as all hell, and yet, she's also grateful. He doesn't ask her to explain that. "You came," she says, quietly awed. "You didn't have to do that for me." "I wanted to," he tells her, then reaches into his jacket and finds her Christmas present. He hadn't remembered why the hell he'd even bought it, hadn't expected there to be a moment like this. "I wanted to make sure you got this." The St. Christopher medallion had been his at one point, when he'd still tried to sort out religion. When reality had set in, he'd stopped wearing it and it had sat there dormant until he'd come across it weeks ago. Somehow, he'd immediately thought of her. Maybe it was the fact that Christopher was the patron saint of holy death, or that he had apparently been revealed as little more than a human martyr, that had prompted him to think of her. She looked from it to him and smiled softly. "Thank you, Jimmy. For this. For being here. For everything else." "You don't have to thank me." He embraced her tightly, holding her close and feeling the happiness he'd brought her turn into peace somewhere inside of himself. In the space of those few moments he had a chance to think about it all. He cared for her, and he always would, most likely. They had crossed the line past friendship at some point, and he believed that it was harder to turn back after that. That it wasn't if men and women could be friends, but that once they decided to be more, then the relationship changed. He knew his and Brittany's relationship had warped from the moment he'd kissed her. But after what had happened in London, he was at peace with knowing they would only ever be friends. He just wanted her to be happy. And if that meant dragging himself to a Christmas party or laying down his life, so be it. He was someone she'd always be able to call a friend, and those were words that would never need to be spoken.

Write a drabble/ficlet on the word "fun." "You need to have some fun," Ryan Sheridan commented, settling himself on the edge of his desk with his soda. He knew better than to settle himself on the edge of his partner's desk. Jimmy McCarron didn't look up from the case file he was compiling. "I'm having fun," he said calmly, without missing a beat in his careful, steady organization. Papers were put in the right order. Notes were made where they needed to be. "No, I mean like the fun that normal people have," Sheridan continued, sipping gently from the Cherry Coke container. "You ever go on a vacation, or rent a movie, or you know, relax?" "Not really." McCarron closed the file, set it aside, and looked at his partner with a firm glance, knowing this discussion would not end unless he stopped it now. "I have fun, Ryan. To me, this is fun. I avenge deaths. I lock up people who need to have their asses thrown in prison. I ensure the justice and order of the city of Los Angeles so that people who have normal lives can sleep well every night. That's what passes for engagement for me, and at least a little for you, or you wouldn't be here." He turned to the next file that lay in waiting. "And even then," he added as Sheridan sighed, knowing the argument to be lost to McCarron's unyielding intensity yet again, "you should know that I'm not normal." The two partners never spoke of the subject again, for McCarron's peace of disposition and Sheridan's safety.

Do you believe in an afterlife? Takes place after the events of Life Serial: The Series episodes 3.2.07 and 3.2.08, but before 3.09. Fic-wise, takes place just before the events of "Reincarnation." "So," McCarron said casually, crossing his legs and watching her eyes as he gestured in her direction, "what do you believe's supposed to happen when you die?" Brittany put down her drink and chewed her lower lip for a moment. They were having a casual lunch before she went back to CTU to do wrap-up on her latest operation. It'd been in Chicago with Tony Almeida and Julian Burroughs, and she'd ended up in Chicago Hope Hospital on the edge of death. Again. When CTU chief medical officer Brian Holt had been notified he'd had an episode, and she still wanted to take the London operation staging in two weeks. To McCarron, it all seemed just a little bit callous. "I don't think about it," she told him. "I'm an atheist, same as you are. I don't believe in God. I just have to see what happens. And I'm not dead yet, so I have some work to do." "Do you just expect us to all show up and cry at your funeral? Did you ever think about that?" he asked her, his voice getting a little hard around the edges. She arched an eyebrow, and her voice hardened, too. "Where are you going with this, Jimmy?" "Damn it, Brittany, you really can't tell?" He leaned back in his chair and stared at her, getting bitter fast and he knew it. "You just throw yourself out there again and again. You don't even think about it or what it's going to do to..." Me. "To anyone. I'd like not to bury you before I have to." There was a hesitation, and then she said, "I didn't know it pissed you off that much, Jimmy." "Doesn't piss me off. It frustrates me. There's a difference." He finally looked at her again. "I don't want to bury you and hope that you go to some grand place you deserve but that I know doesn't really exist. I want you to be happy and still be breathing. Until then, you'd better keep yourself alive. I don't think that's too much to ask of you, is it?" She just shook her head, and he sighed and refilled her glass. She didn't look up for a long moment, and he didn't say anything, letting her have her peace. She was everything. She didn't get to throw her life away and turn that into nothing at all. What do you want for your birthday? I've never really cared about my birthday that much at all. Yeah, when I was growing up and at the academy, I'd maybe go out with a few friends for a few hours. But with more important things on my mind and no one standing by, it's become irrelevant. Another year alive, another year fighting. That's what's important to me now. It only got stranger after I met Brittany. October 19 is the day she lost a childhood friend of hers in a car accident. To her it's a day of mourning. She wants to be happy for me, but she made a promise to him to not forget, and every year she goes home to visit him where he's buried, no matter what else is happening. It's the anniversary of loss to her. I went with her this year, and I know that she'll be thinking about him on that day, and she should. We have every other day together; this is the only day she gets with him anymore. It's not really about what I want ... it's about what I've got left to do. A day to look at the calendar and realize one more year is done and I've still got a mission left to complete. But I guess if I really had to think of something... I'd want her to be happy. I'd like to find some way, however backward, to let her be comfortable in her own skin on that day. To take the weight, take the pain, take the guilt, and replace it with peace, comfort, hope. She's a good woman, one of the best people I've ever known, and she deserves the best for standing by me when everyone else told her I was a lost cause to be written off or handled. No, she trusts me, she respects me, and I care about her more than I've ever cared about anyone. When she's honestly happy, part of me is happy for her. If I can give her that in the middle of all the shit we go through to save the world from itself, that would be enough for me. And you know what? Michael finally married her. She's been promoted to Assistant Special Agent In Charge. She's got new friends and new allies. The Code Five invasion is finally, truthfully over, and with it she and Michael can bury their shared ghosts of that and move on. I look in his eyes and I see someone different than the man I once disrespected because he disrespected her. I understand now why they're soulmates and I know they've found their way to each other. We don't need Code Black anymore. We don't need to fear anything anymore. For all of us, fighting that last engagement in London was a big turning point. Michael and I both understand that we both love her and we will both be here for her, always. She doesn't need to worry about us anymore. She has a real chance, the first real chance in years, to honestly just live for a little while. So maybe I've already given her what I want for her.

Who would you like to see get their final comeuppance? What would you do with them? You shouldn't ask me that question. In terms of retribution, the sins of Deputy District Attorney David McNorris are myriad. I don't care what Brittany or anyone else says about the man worth saving inside or the hell of a lawyer he can be, I've seen what he really is inside. How he can manipulate his own people for his own twisted ends. How he will stop at nothing to get what he wants. They tell me he's got a closet full of demons to answer to, but it's not good enough for me. Not when I've seen him call Brittany in over and over, handing her assignments that have almost gotten her killed, knowing she'll do the job because she feels she's doing the "right thing" and can't look away from a problem. He's the one who sent her in after those corrupt cops, a decision which led to her having to kill a couple of people just to save herself, something which made her think she'd become a truly horrible person. It stripped a woman of great heart and talent of her self-worth and her self-respect, to say nothing of the lives it cost and the trauma it put loved ones through, and he fucking thought of the whole thing as collateral damage. Not when he's tried to get T.J. bounced out of S.W.A.T. for things he didn't do, knowing full well that T.J.'s whole life is that job. McCabe's got his own sins, and if he fucks up, he deserves to be punished for them. If he gets fired over this bar fight, he deserves it. But to do that to him when he's done nothing wrong, knowing full well that it'll leave him with nothing and probably traumatize him for life, especially when I know he'll likely put a gun to his head hours later, is just the work of a heartless asshole out to make an example of a convenient target. Not when I've seen him put pressure on Ryan, Captain Hagermann, even Frank. Yeah, I feel for Frank. We might not be friends, but that doesn't mean he gets to be shoved around. None of them deserve that. They're doing their job and they deserve to be able to do it. Robbery Homicide Division isn't his personal crusade, and we're not his expendable soldiers. They fight back, but they think there's only so much they can do, fearing a wrath we can't see. I don't have that fear; I never have. He wants to touch me, bring it on. He's tried often enough, and he's failed every time. There's a confrontation on the horizon, just the two of us, no surrender, no retreat, no compromises. He and I will go head-to-head someday soon. It will be a violent, intense as all hell showdown where it'll all be put out on the table. Only one of us will be standing when it's through. So you shouldn't ask me that question. Because I'm one of those people who doesn't just talk - I follow through.

What was the best 24 hours you've ever had? There was a chance that they were going to die. Once they knew the odds, once the words 'invasion' and 'insurgence' had been thrown around in the Division office of Stephen Claire, it became clear to the members of Code Black that the Code Five contingent in Los Angeles was a hell of a lot bigger than a couple-man hit squad sent to take down Michael Colefield, never mind that he'd fled the country at least a month before. He was probably still the target, but they were talking about at least a dozen, if not more, against the four of them. Three to one odds, minimum. It would have been five, but Brittany was busy running CTU Los Angeles as Acting Special Agent In Charge. McCarron had no doubt they knew about her, too, and considered her an enemy combatant given that she'd saved Colefield's life the first time out. This time it'd be up to him, alongside T.J. McCabe, Eric Weiss and Claire. He only trusted T.J., but the fact that Brittany trusted the other two was good enough. He was willing to fight with them. They argued in Claire's office for maybe an hour or two, planning and plotting, but McCarron's blood was already surging in his veins. He knew it was all buying time they were already borrowing. He would lead them into a war for Los Angeles, and unlike Michael Colefield in London, he would not fail. He was their leader. Not Claire, who was a former Baltimore SWAT cop and veteran CTU agent experienced enough that he was called upon in some of the most important games of state. Not Weiss, who had been part of the first encounter and had saved Brittany's own life. She hadn't asked them. She had turned to him. She had looked him in the eyes and said, "When this goes down, and it will go down, it's not gonna be my call, it's gonna be your call." He had not asked for an explanation. She had not provided one. He is the leader of Code Black and he will lead them tonight. They arm up with the munitions and weapons sent from overseas and head downstairs to the van that's waiting. Their mission is one no one can ever learn about. The woman who put them together can't help them now. They know there's a chance someone will be sacrificed. No one talks about it. It's not on Jimmy McCarron's mind. He wants the next fight, the next chance, and he has the biggest one of all staring him in the face. He stares it down. Over the next twenty-four hours they make strategic strike after strategic strike - no trial runs, no preparation, just winner-take-all, no-prisoners open combat. The United States has gone to war with Iraq, the Counter Terrorist Unit is on full alert, and he is yelling that no one leaves alive as he ducks an incoming attack in an abandoned art gallery. T.J. stumbles down the stairs, dragging his target with him, and the walls shake as one Code Five is disincentivized, but he doesn't keep score. He'll do that by how many people are breathing at the end. Weiss loses his target, yells for someone's help as the Code Five leaps through a plate glass window to the alley below. McCarron is closest and makes a running jump before anyone can tell him not to, not caring if he gets hurt in the three-story drop. He lands on his feet, fires two shots without looking that hit the Code Five in the back. He stands firm in the face of the explosion that follows, his heart pounding methodically, his blood pulsing with the rush of adrenaline that sings inside of him. He has never been this alive. The situation repeats itself time after time in the space of this day. It is just before two a.m. Thursday when he phones her from the van, bruised and bloodied but resolute as Stephen Claire sits in the van tending to a massive wound in his arm. He tells her that this is their last move, that they are well aware that this is the nerve center and that they may not get back alive. She tries to say something, but he cuts her off. He doesn't want to hear it. He hangs up and looks at the others behind him, hurting badly. They wonder at his coldness. They don't know that Jimmy McCarron lives for the fight, is driven by the relentless, righteous intensity for justice that is in his head and in his heart, that he pushes hard for and yet almost fears the day when the fighting is done. They don't know that in fighting he finds himself. They may never know, but he doesn't care. Everything else is secondary to the fight he's been fighting his whole life, of which this is just the next, largest, most important chapter. When their backs are to the wall ten minutes later he faces it like birth. Blood is down his face and in his mouth and he's in the middle of it. This is the fiercest fight he has ever been in and he feels better than he ever has, despite the fact that each moment is borrowed time. If he goes down, he will go down hard and take someone with him. All the ferocity, all the righteousness, all the intensity blazes and burns in him, pushes him forward, pushes him harder. The others may taste only the pain, but it's all within him now, and he focuses it and makes something of it. They may keep coming, but he has never feared his own death. And in the middle of that there's the moment of heroic clarity. He knows they're outnumbered, and he thinks through the eyes of the woman that would have been their leader. He pushes past his own dislike of the man to call Frank Smith and have him summon her. What he doesn't expect is that she'll come running fully intent to be the sacrifice he suspected was coming. She'll throw herself down upon the altar and she will scream for him to get the hell out and save himself, and that's when he'll make the choice she would have made, take the control in spirit as well as force. For this night, he will own fate. He will summon more than he thought he could be and he will save her life. He will defy her and defy the sacrifice and the intended order of the world by willpower alone. He will assert himself as a leader and a hero and on his shoulders they'll find the victory resting. It will end because he decides it will end. When he's standing in the hallway as she lays on the operating table, considering life and death and how much it all means to him, he'll know he has never been so alone, and he has never been so alive.

What was the biggest lie you've ever told? What were the consequences? Jimmy McCarron doesn't lie unless he has a damn good reason to do so. He's lied to murderers, murder suspects, witnesses that need coercion, but that kind of deception is part of his job. Otherwise, he unflinchingly tells the truth, whether you're prepared to hear it or not. It may have alienated people over the years, but that's the price you pay. It's reality, and it should be faced, not handled, in his eyes. So the only severe lying he's ever done has been to himself. He insisted for the better part of a year and a half that what he felt happening inside of himself wasn't love, wasn't attraction, when he knew damn well that was what it was. He fought against it, telling himself that it would only expose vulnerabilities he could not afford to have. There were justifications for his silence as she went back to Michael Colefield, a man he'd only ever seen as trouble. He always had his reasons why, the most prominent being that this wasn't supposed to happen. McCarron lied to himself right up until the point where he saw the engagement ring on her finger. And he lied to her right up until the night before her marriage. By then the fates were already cast. Both of them, believing in marriage and fidelity, would never consent to her leaving her fiance at the altar, especially when said fiance was a man with little else concrete in his life but her. By then, he'd seen what she saw in Michael and understood that yes, he was worthy of her, maybe he had been all along. He told her that for her future, she needed to follow through. He told her he knew what it meant. She married Michael the next day, while he looked on trying to pretend it didn't hurt him inside. Over the months since, the pain has died but it will never fade. It was too brutal, too long in denial, for that. He didn't make his move because it was a battle he never wanted to fight. He knows now the consequences of losing when she leaves him after every day or case or lunch meeting. He'll never get to be the one she comes to, just the one she leaves. He accepts it, knowing he brought that on himself by the one lie he ever told.

What would you put in a personal ad if you were making one? I don't do well with talking about my personal life. Leave that to Brittany, the professional writer, or Frank, who used to spend a lot of time taking her to John Cusack movies, or any of them. They can articulate their thoughts and feelings. What makes you feel vulnerable, and what makes you feel invulnerable, and why? Jimmy McCarron didn't consider his vulnerabilities until he was taken under by the biggest one of them all. He was human; he had vulnerabilities and he knew that, and with a certain Zen philosophy he learned what he could and how to defend against them. In fact, he knew himself with a clear-cut precision that was disturbingly like he was talking about someone else. He could anticipate his moves like a chess player, know his emotions like the back of his hand, and that made it easy to handle the flaws in his life without too much collateral damage. No one weakness could be exploited for little more than a moment of hatred, a random obscenity, or maybe an unconscious form hitting the floor. It was something he had worked very hard on, a very fine bridgework he was proud of. Then he fell in love. She was his vulnerability now, or she was molding them under her careful, idealistic hands. Her more acceptable, more perfect qualities were slowly stripping away his necessary, unconventional traits with each encounter. He could never be like her, but being with her made him want to try, and that made him weak. He needed to be able to be drastic, to be violent, to be tough if it was necessary to do so. Yet the more he was with her, he wanted to fall in line, to find simpler solutions, to compromise. He saw in her first the darkness, but now she was finding herself in him and he had to deny her if he had any hope of being the man he had to be. Of course, he had never asked her about any of these things. She would likely say it wasn't so, or try to accept him as he was, against her better instincts. He knew her about as well as he knew himself, and she would always be ruled by her more acceptable half. She could never drop the mask she played by and she would therefore never know the rules by which he had to play his role. So they moved together and apart, McCarron and the woman he loved, philosophy in their affair. Slowly now more of his drastic actions were for her victory or her revenge. Subtly now she would unleash the pain he had taught her to hold on to for moments when she needed to be tough or face the consequences. While she began to lose her grace, he began to find his. This disturbed him the longer it went on, because they could not be the same person, lest they both be lost. She made him vulnerable. T.J.'s not there when they arrive at the mock building course. He was supposed to be one of the team members on this prep course - it was part of why they both signed up for it. McCarron doesn't call. It's not his place, anymore. He just suits up. He and Brittany will go this one alone.

"You wonder where he is?" she asks as she adjusts the bulletproof vest.

He tests the feel of the assault rifle on his shoulder. "Not really." T.J. now is a mere spectre in the back of his mind. The lingering darkness beyond his vision. The physical manifestation, the body memory, of life gone wrong.

The other team member who's not T.J. - somebody named Sanchez - sets them loose. For McCarron, it is a fairly easy transition as his brain clicks over past its own imposed limits. He knows Brittany is looking for rationalization. Grabbing her hand pulls her beyond that. When they're down behind the first barricade he's close enough to whisper in her ear.

"You and me, okay? That's all there has to be."

She nods, readjusting her grip on the handgun she chose to stick with. "I go down, I go down, you hear me?" she tells him, sounding surprisingly assertive. "You don't protect me. You don't come back for me."

He gives her a barely imperceptible nod. It's as close to a promise as he'll get.

A three-count and they're up and firing. He's surprisingly fast, chillingly accurate. Maybe it's T.J.'s lessons that it did it. After a moment more, she's gone, covering his next angle. He watches her reload, one violent slam of a new clip into the weapon, another target. 

There's always another target; she has made a living out of taking them down, if not of being one herself. Maybe she doesn't kill them, maybe she can't, but she knows when to pick her shots. That's the thing with her. He can see the wheels turning in her mind as the bullets fly loose.

As he squeezes the trigger, McCarron knows he'd break that promise in a heartbeat.

He moves to his next target. There's always another target.

He's made a living out of taking them out for good.

If you won the equivalent of $2,000, and had to spend it, what would you spend it on? Jimmy McCarron's first thought - after rolling his eyes - is what Brittany would do with it. It's her job, to keep the place running, and he knows she knows the inside of what it really costs for people like the two of them to keep on fighting. He knows, with an amused little smile, she probably turned around and put all of it right back into the CTU system, or charity, or something that wasn't her. So he makes his first decision: to go and find her something for all the times she's given up what she had for other people. The obvious choice involves baseball, as he knows she and Frank have been going to Padres games together even after the split. There was something she made reference to once - an Adam Eaton jersey that was going to run her something like $350 that she couldn't convince herself she needed that badly. It's small compared to all the things she's done for him, but if it makes her happy, that's all he cares about. As for the rest of it? He supposes he owes his partner for putting up with him over these years, which isn't an easy thing by anyone's standards. If there's something he can do for Ryan and Jenna, they've only got to name it. Captain Hagermann, too, for the leadership that often goes unnoticed in the storm that days with her detectives can often become. They've done their part of the work - now it's his turn.

They took separate cars to Hollywood and Highland. Frank couldn't stand being in the Alero with Breaking Benjamin screaming on "Sooner or Later." McCarron couldn't stand being in the car with Frank. This kept them silent as they met each other and Frank led the way to The Highland. All the while, McCarron was trying to figure out what his game was.

The nightclub, at least that's what it was called, was actually resembling more of an Olive Garden. That seemed redundant, as according to Frank's pointless commentary an Olive Garden already existed on the premises. It was where he'd taken Brittany on their second date, but he didn't say that because he rightly figured McCarron didn't really want to hear anything about people who weren't him. He'd gone through that phase himself.

She was waiting for them just off the door, in the shade of the entryway where she'd once been standing during her tryout for that ESPN reality show. She didn't really talk about it, but it had been one of those things she'd done when she'd had a normal life. Frank hugs her tightly, kisses her on the cheek; Jimmy lets him have his clingy moment before giving her shoulder a reassuring squeeze.

Brittany pockets her sunglasses and looks at Frank with an impish smile. "You got him to come. I'm impressed."

"Hey, for you, I'll try anything once."

McCarron looks at them both. "Why am I here?" he interrupts bluntly.

"Is it a crime to have the two of you both out with me at the same time?" She laughs a little. "Because I asked, Jimmy. And because I've got some stuff to say I think you both might want to hear."

They head into the restaurant and end up at a table by the badly-lit bar. Brittany takes the chair between the two of them; so old instincts haven't completely faded. She'd still rather have her and a table between the two of them. Frank doesn't notice, but McCarron applauds her intelligence. Frank Smith is not his friend, and they'd both do good to remember that.

"We got a new CIA A.D. today," she tells them, sipping at her water. "Met with him this morning. Richard Durant, out of Operations."

Frank is curious and concerned at the same time. He doesn't know the first thing about intelligence, even after all these years. "What's that mean for you?" he asks her, chin on his forearms, looking at her with piqued eyes. It's charming in a pathetic way, McCarron thinks, how he loves her still, in that clingy sense.

"Don't know. The guy knows what he wants and how to get it. Either he's going to help us or hurt us, but I don't see there being a middle ground." She swallows. "The point is I don't know how he's going to react to me working with you guys, with everybody else. If he wants me to focus within the Agency, I've gotta do what he says. Anyone who's seen the reality knows her bringing the L.A. community's figureheads together has done wonders for the city's law enforcement structure. Remove her, and Deputy D.A. McNorris never gets on the same page as RHD. Remove her, and he's killed Frank by now.

"I have no fucking clue. The man scares me. Well, not scares, but he's off-putting." She sighs. "Ex-MP, ex-internal. And it's like he knows way too much about me. He knew who to talk to and what to ask them. He knows the way it goes."

The RHD detective nods. "Just means the playing field's finally level."

Brittany has to admit, as she stares uncomfortably into her water glass, that he's right.

Jimmy McCarron is sitting at his desk, paging a book on police supervision that he'd forgotten to read, respecting the relative peace and calm of a Los Angeles afternoon. For this small section of time, no bodies are falling. No police dispatchers are putting out any calls for a Robbery Homicide Division detective. There's no one he needs to yell at in an interrogation room. For about twenty minutes now, he can relax and work on other things deserving of his attention. "Interesting reading?" McCarron looks up with an arched eyebrow to see Frank Smith standing in front of him. He reflects then that it was much easier to deal with these situations when they hated each other, making snide comments and heated glares their language. These days he doesn't know what the hell Frank wants, and Frank's ever-composed attitude could mean anything. Inwardly, he rolls his eyes. "Yeah, it is. What do you want?" "Brittany and I were going out for a late lunch. I thought you might want to come along." Now McCarron's brain temporarily freezes. Is this Frank Smith, golden boy of Los Angeles RHD and general Boy Scout, actually inviting his former nemesis along on a get-together with his beloved ex-girlfriend? Never mind what the rest of the universe would think, this sentence is a freak aberration of everything about their uneasy relationship. He's still trying to deduce this as he formulates an answer. "Frank, what the hell?" he finally just says. Frank obviously didn't expect that one. "We're going to lunch at The Highland. She asked how you were. I didn't see any reason why you couldn't be there. You want to come?" "This isn't some sort of personal thing between you two?" "We're having lunch, we're not discussing world peace." It's a decent dose of sarcasm, which is a huge risk in talking to Jimmy McCarron. The fact that Frank is willing to employ it signals to McCarron that he's genuine. Finally, McCarron sighs and puts down the book. "Fine, I'll be there. What time are you leaving?" "About half an hour. She's meeting me there." Smith turns to head back to his desk. He almost looks like he wants to say something else, but he doesn't. McCarron stares at the back of his head. This cannot be happening. There's something going on here.
